title: Prakrit
summary: The Prakrits (/ˈprɑːkrɪt/; Early Brahmi 𑀧𑁆𑀭𑀸𑀓𑀾𑀢, prākṛta;[1] Devanagari Sanskrit: प्राकृत, prākṛta; Shauraseni: 𑀧𑀸𑀉𑀤, pāuda; Jain Prakrit: pāua; Kannada: pāgada; Tamil: pāgadam) are a group of vernacular Middle Indo-Aryan languages used in India from around the 3rd century BCE to the 8th century CE.[2][3] The term Prakrit is usually applied to the middle period of Middle Indo-Aryan languages, excluding earlier inscriptions and the later Pali.[4] The Prakrits were used contemporaneously with the Classical Sanskrit of higher social classes.[5] Prākṛta literally means "natural", as opposed to saṃskṛta, which literally means "constructed" or "refined".[4]
